text: it's great to be here and I really
appreciate everyone hanging around into
the end of the day to hear these keynote
presentations it's excellent to see the
interest here in China today I want to
talk a little bit about the virtuous
cycle of open source that we have found
that comes about through organizations
working out in open governance creating
software that we can all take advantage
of and use and how that's affected the
world and and you know where we see
things going forward so let me get
started in this I've been with IBM for a
very long time and over the last 20
years I've been involved in open source
and and as I sat and thought about what
was happening in open source
I sort of pinned things down to a very
pivotal moment in the history of open
source with Linux Linux really was sort
of a lynchpin turning point for really
being able to see large numbers of
developers come together around the
project to do good for the world
everybody can sort of remember Peace
Love and Linux right that was a slogan
that was out at that time
creating free software to go and drive
the world it was a great thing
developers were energized by that they
could come together they could do
something as a community and as a result
of that really really solve for the
world and and we see the end result of
that where Linux is everywhere now it
runs our world it provides the operating
system not only for servers but for the
devices that we have virtually
everything is is tied to Linux these
days it's an incredible story so but but
that story was sort of galvanized when
IBM in particular made a billion dollar
pledge to develop Linux right suddenly
here was a large company who was willing
to put a bet on an open technology to
bring in to enterprises who were
traditionally very skeptical of
open-source software and and it made
companies really stand up and take
notice not only that but we made a
pledge to not assert our patents
against the the kernel of the Linux
kernel and and that was a big deal and
we actually went on to found the open
invention Network oh I am that that went
and got others to pledge their patents
such that we protected Linux and could
see it grow and move into the future
well that project really kicked things
off then we saw a patchy form and the
HTTP server become the standard right
suddenly code was the de facto standard
that was enabling scale to happen and
and projects to come to life and and it
was a wonderful thing to go and see
Eclipse another big milestone along this
path the Eclipse project was seeded with
30 million dollars of software from us
and and became a staple out there and in
the Java community in the world and on
and on and on we saw more projects come
out over time coming together built-in
open governance working to do you know
great things for the world in the
community but being used by businesses
now to go and build what they believed
were you know the applications for the
future for them and and this cycle
continued well about hello six seven
eight years ago we saw you know projects
like OpenStack come about right we're a
group of companies came together and
very quickly formed a project out into
the open and under open governance and
we saw an ecosystem very much spring up
around that and and great things happen
in adoption of that around the world and
in that continued into Cloud Foundry we
saw nodejs come about of course
kubernetes projects like hyper ledger
which are you know changing the way we
do the world through blockchain see the
world through blockchain and of course
cloud native technologies you know just
a few years ago the cloud native
computing foundation came about and and
I'm also I'll you know be transparent
I'm the the chairman of the governing
board for the cloud native computing
foundation and it came about because we
all as a group of
companies felt that we could build the
infrastructure create a new world around
cloud native and and bring together
technologies that everyone could use and
depend on and do it together and not
compete on building the plumbing because
now the plumbing was ubiquitous we all
could go and share in the development of
that and and so we started out with a
couple of projects kubernetes and
Prometheus and and maybe 40 or so
companies today we sit here with 333
companies who have come together and but
some 18 projects couple have graduated
and the rest in incubation that are
really wonderful examples of the cloud
native so but in that we sort of lost
the the the feel for doing things as
small coders and developers that that
peace love and Linux feel was great at
the beginning but it sort of sort of
left us so what happened we partnered up
with the UN the Red Cross and others and
I came out here about four months ago
with with a group of folks and we did
lots of talks around how to get involved
in the call for code and and we wanted
to reach out to the 22 million
developers of the world a hundred
thousand developers responded it's
across 156 countries we had 352 events
that went and ran groups to go and code
around this 2,500 submissions
one winner got a $200,000 prize and that
was a mesh network which was there to
help first responders so what did IBM do
we're gonna go help now take that
project to production but I know you
should be really proud because China
answered the call for code as well 211
partner sprung up to help go and promote
this one team actually became one of the
top five finalists and this was done by
the green coda project from the
Agricultural Bank of China and what they
did is they created a project
was a very complex piece of software
they had blockchain and cloud
technologies and they used the cloud
along with databases and other things to
build a complex app that when people
lost everything as part of a disaster
they could go up to a ATM through facial
recognition get money and and that was
all secured transactions over blockchain
it was really a nice thing to go and see
now they didn't win but they came up in
the top five and their project will be
highlighted on the Linux Foundation
pages and become an open-source project
for the Linux Foundation so what enabled
that well IDM loves kubernetes our whole
infrastructure that we allowed people to
go and build those applications on is up
and available on our cloud and and we've
moved our Watson services and other
services all onto that infrastructure so
when people think about the IBM cloud
they should be thinking about kubernetes
in our container service and gradually
everything that we're doing that's
beyond base will move over onto it so so
those dream coder folks were able to
take advantage of this and build it out
so if we could just quickly queue the
demo this is just a short video of what
they were able to take advantage of
basically logging in getting into the
dashboard finding the features that they
wanted to do they wanted to get a
kubernetes service up and going they
created a new cluster it's a highly
available cluster multi zone cluster
that allows them to you know pick their
locations and deploy if you need to have
GPU capabilities which they did in this
case they're able to go pick servers
with GPU capabilities they can deploy
those containers down on to bare metal
servers to get the absolute most
performance and and here we see you know
choosing the servers to go and do that
and they're up and can then go and
deploy create the cluster and finalize
it and get it going
okay here we go almost in production do
we hang there we go oh so now let's if
you look at it they were then able to go
into our catalog and it's a nicely
organized catalog right after this and
and go and pick the services that they
wanted to use to go and do this such as
a database right all done through helm
charts all deployed out and there was
this core of services that they had
access to that became the basic way that
they were able to build their
application get going all done in a very
very short period of time four months so
it it's a wonderful thing to go and see
we've now created a way that developers
can go from being you know mostly
business developers who are working in
companies out working in open-source
come back around to do good things for
the community the call for code is going
to go on for five years and this is just
the first year of the cycle we hope all
of you can come and join us and continue
to be part of that virtuous cycle so
thank you
[Applause]
